aws::graph::propositions: # Pilot and Aircraft Incident Information
The pilot held a Private certificate.
The pilot was 57 years old.
The pilot had airplane ratings for Single-engine land and Multi-engine land.
The pilot occupied the Left seat.
The pilot had no Other Aircraft Ratings.
The pilot used a 3-point restraint.
The pilot had an Instrument Rating for Airplane.
No Second Pilot was present.
The pilot had no Instructor Ratings.
No toxicology was performed on the pilot.
The pilot held a Class 3 Medical Certification with waivers/limitations.
The pilot's last FAA Medical Exam was on April 2, 2014.
The pilot was not an Occupational Pilot.
The pilot's last Flight Review or Equivalent was on January 13, 2014.
The pilot had 4300 hours of total flight time across all aircraft.
The pilot had 1300 hours of total flight time in this make and model.
The pilot had 4250 hours as Pilot In Command across all aircraft.
The pilot had 75 hours of flight time in the last 90 days across all aircraft.
The pilot had 25 hours of flight time in the last 30 days across all aircraft.
The number 6 connecting rod was fractured into five pieces.
The number 6 connecting rod pieces displayed thermal discoloration and mechanical damage.
The piston end of the connecting rod remained attached to the piston pin.
The oil feed to the number 6 bearing was mechanically damaged at the number 6 connecting rod journal.
The oil feed was unobstructed at the number 4 main journal end.
Remnants of the connecting rod bearing were found in the oil sump.
The connecting rod bearing remnants were thermally discolored and distorted.
The internal configuration of two engine crankshaft oil tube assemblies for the number 5 and 6 connecting rods was documented using radiographic images.
The radiographic images were collected on May 4 and 5, 2015, in Chicago, Illinois.
A total of 360 computed tomography (CT) slice images were examined, processed, and analyzed by the NTSB.
The NTSB analyzed the CT images to evaluate the component.

text:
# Pilot Information

## Certificate: 
Private

## Age:
57

## Airplane Rating(s):
Single-engine land, Multi-engine land

## Seat Occupied:
Left

## Other Aircraft Rating(s):
None

## Restraint Used:
3-point

## Instrument Rating(s):
Airplane

## Second Pilot Present:
No

## Instructor Rating(s):
None

## Toxicology Performed:
No

## Medical Certification:
Class 3 With waivers/limitations

## Last FAA Medical Exam:
April 2, 2014

## Occupational Pilot:
No

## Last Flight Review or Equivalent:
January 13, 2014

## Flight Time:
4300 hours (Total, all aircraft), 1300 hours (Total, this make and model), 4250 hours (Pilot In Command, all aircraft), 75 hours (Last 90 days, all aircraft), 25 hours (Last 30 days, all aircraft)

The number 6 connecting rod was fractured into five pieces, and all displayed thermal discoloration and mechanical damage. The piston end of the connecting rod remained attached to the piston pin. The oil feed to the number 6 bearing was mechanically damaged at the number 6 connecting rod journal; however, it was unobstructed at the number 4 main journal end. Remnants of the connecting rod bearing were found in the oil sump. The remnants were thermally discolored and distorted.

The internal configuration of two engine crankshaft oil tube assemblies for the number 5 and 6 connecting rods was documented using radiographic images that were collected on May 4 and 5, 2015, in Chicago, Illinois. A total of 360 computed tomography (CT) slice images were examined, processed, and analyzed by the NTSB to evaluate the component.
